
<!-- README.md is generated from README.Rmd. Please edit that file -->

# regconfint

<!-- badges: start -->
<!-- badges: end -->

The goal of regconfint is to estimate point estimate with their
bootstrap confidence intervals for regularized regression coefficients.
The function supports various regression families. For elastic-net, the
function supports automatic alpha selection when multiple alpha values
are provided, and it also allows for parallel computation to optimize
performance.

## Installation

You can install the development version of regconfint from
[GitHub](https://github.com/) with:

``` r
# install.packages("pak")
pak::pak("kitanota/regconfint")
```

## Example

``` r
library(regconfint)
#Data set creation
n <- 500
x1 <- rnorm(n, mean = 50, sd = 10)
x2 <- rnorm(n, mean = 100, sd = 15)
x3 <- rnorm(n, mean = 30, sd = 5)
x4 <- rnorm(n, mean = 70, sd = 20)
x5 <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5)
x6 <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.3)
x7 <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.7)
x <- data.frame(x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, x6, x7)
num_var <- ncol(x)

#Binary outcome
y_1 <- 3* x1 - 2 * x2 + x3 + 0.5 * x4 + x5 * 3 + x6 * (-4) + x7 * 6 + rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = 20)
prob <- 1 / (1 + exp(-y_1))
prob[prob>1] <- 1
prob[prob<0] <- 0
y <- rbinom(n, 1, prob)
dataset <- data.frame(x,y)
print(dataset)
#>           x1        x2       x3        x4 x5 x6 x7 y

#> 500 48.81124 115.98085 28.18592  68.28922  0  0  1 0

#gaussian with identity-link

# Ridge regression
ridge_RD <- regconfint(dataset, expv=c("x1", "x2", "x3", "x4", "x5", "x6", "x7"), tarv="y", itr=10, al=0, sed=1234, fam="gaussian", lin="identity")

# Lasso regression
lasso_RD <- regconfint(dataset, expv=c("x1", "x2", "x3", "x4", "x5", "x6", "x7"), tarv="y", itr=10, al=1, sed=1234, fam="gaussian", lin="identity")

# Elastic-net
El_RD <- regconfint(dataset, expv=c("x1", "x2", "x3", "x4", "x5", "x6", "x7"), tarv="y", itr=5, al=seq(0.01,0.99,0.01), sed=1234, fam="gaussian",lin="identity", paral="Y")

# Bias-corrected bootstrap confidence intervals for ridge
BC_CI <- bc_ci(ridge_RD,conf=0.95)
print(BC_CI)
#>             X1           X2
#> 1  0.020994070  0.024022902
#> 2 -0.014667867 -0.013451513
#> 3  0.009100446  0.017025291
#> 4  0.001568133  0.003969043
#> 5  0.010699743  0.091999677
#> 6 -0.073458098  0.007637162
#> 7 -0.041569081  0.017716968

# Percentile bootstrap confidence intervals for ridge
 for (i in 1:num_var) { bt <- boot::boot.ci(ridge_RD,type="perc",index=i)
 print(c("CI of variable_",i))
 print(c(bt$t0,bt$percent[4:5])) }
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "1"

#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "4"              
#> [1] 0.003028478 0.001553953 0.004681557
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "5"              
#> [1] 0.042429781 0.009621066 0.092430254
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "6"              
#> [1] -0.03536312 -0.07353086  0.02367306
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "7"              
#> [1]  0.0007956707 -0.0416727793  0.0654820580

#Poisson with log-link

# Ridge regression
ridge_RR <- regconfint(dataset, expv=c("x1", "x2", "x3", "x4", "x5", "x6", "x7"), tarv="y", itr=10, al=0, sed=1234, fam="poisson", lin="log")

# Lasso regression
lasso_RR <- regconfint(dataset, expv=c("x1", "x2", "x3", "x4", "x5", "x6", "x7"), tarv="y", itr=10, al=1, sed=1234, fam="poisson", lin="log")
# Elastic-net
El_RR <- regconfint(dataset, expv=c("x1", "x2", "x3", "x4", "x5", "x6", "x7"), tarv="y", itr=5, al=seq(0.01,0.99,0.01), sed=1234, fam="poisson",lin="log", paral="N")

# If paral = "Y", parallel computing will be implemented based on the number of cores available in your computer

# Bias-corrected bootstrap confidence intervals for ridge
BC_CI <- bc_ci(ridge_RR,conf=0.95)
print(BC_CI)
#>             X1           X2
#> 1  0.030476456  0.037495871
#> 2 -0.023213313 -0.019557863
#> 3  0.015760942  0.027342788
#> 4  0.002562213  0.006381203
#> 5  0.013403915  0.158644901
#> 6 -0.129669993  0.041447886
#> 7 -0.055829864  0.053732884

# Percentile bootstrap confidence intervals for ridge
# For other types of confidence intervals, modify the type argument. For more details, please see the instruction of boot pakage
for (i in 1:num_var) { bt <- boot::boot.ci(ridge_RR,type="perc",index=i)
print(c("CI of variable_",i))
print(c(bt$t0,bt$percent[4:5])) }
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "1"              
#> [1] 0.03393613 0.02853871 0.03754520
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "2"              
#> [1] -0.02132718 -0.02330923 -0.01943871
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "3"              
#> [1] 0.02156609 0.01573456 0.03029649
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "4"              
#> [1] 0.004749854 0.002540155 0.007132174
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "5"              
#> [1] 0.066576541 0.009078107 0.160791129
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "6"              
#> [1] -0.04906735 -0.13029804  0.05644785
#> Warning in norm.inter(t, alpha): extreme order statistics used as endpoints
#> [1] "CI of variable_" "7"              
#> [1] -0.00897607 -0.05589011  0.10472621
```

What is special about using `README.Rmd` instead of just `README.md`?
You can include R chunks like so:

``` r
summary(cars)
#>      speed           dist       
#>  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
#>  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
#>  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
#>  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
#>  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
#>  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
```

You’ll still need to render `README.Rmd` regularly, to keep `README.md`
up-to-date. `devtools::build_readme()` is handy for this.

You can also embed plots, for example:

<img src="man/figures/README-pressure-1.png" width="100%" />

In that case, don’t forget to commit and push the resulting figure
files, so they display on GitHub and CRAN.
